sections.text:
Accepted Manuscript
Title: Nano nickel oxide coated graphene/polyaniline composite film with high electrochemical performance for flexible supercapacitor
Author: Xinming Wu Qiguan Wang Wenzhi Zhang Yan Wang Weixing Chen
PII: S0013-4686(16)31343-3 DOI: http://dx.doi.org/doi:10.1016/j.electacta.2016.06.026 Reference: EA 27465
To appear in: Electrochimica Acta
Received date: 21-3-2016 Revised date: 12-5-2016 Accepted date: 4-6-2016
Please cite this article as: Xinming Wu, Qiguan Wang, Wenzhi Zhang, Yan Wang, Weixing Chen, Nano nickel oxide coated graphene/polyaniline composite film with high electrochemical performance for flexible supercapacitor, Electrochimica Acta http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.electacta.2016.06.026
This is a PDF file of an unedited manuscript that has been accepted for publication. As a service to our customers we are providing this early version of the manuscript. The manuscript will undergo copyediting, typesetting, and review of the resulting proof before it is published in its final form. Please note that during the production process errors may be discovered which could affect the content, and all legal disclaimers that apply to the journal pertain.
Nano nickel oxide coated graphene/polyaniline composite film with high electrochemical performance for flexible supercapacitor
Xinming Wu*, Qiguan Wang, Wenzhi Zhang ,Yan Wang, Weixing Chen
(School of Materials Science and Chemical Engineering, Xi’an Technological University, Xi’an 710032, P. R. China)
 Corresponding author: XM. Wu (), Tel: +8613720456279; fax: +86 29 88431680 . E-mail address: Aimar_wu@aliyun.com.cn
Highlights:  A novel nano nickel oxide coated graphene/polyaniline composites was prepared.  NiO-GNS/PANI shows a high supercapacitive performance of 1409 F g-1.  The specific capacitance retains 92% after 2500 charge-discharge.  NiO-GNS/PANI maintains 86% capacity retention after 1000 bending tests.
Abstract: A nano nickel oxide coated graphene/polyaniline (NiO-GNS/PANI) nanostructure is designed and synthesized as electrode material for flexible supercapacitor application via hydrothermal and in situ chemical oxidative polymerization methods. It is found that this nanostructure exhibits outstanding electrochemical performances, such as high specific capacitance (1409 F g-1 at 1.0 A g-1) and good cycling stability (92% capacity retention after 2500 cycles at 1.0 A g-1). The enhanced electrochemical performance of this ternary composite is due to high surface area, low internal resistance, reduction of diffusion length and synergistic effect between individual constituents. A flexible thin-film supercapacitor is fabricated using NiO-GNS/PANI, which presents excellent electrochemical stability at different angles (0-900) and long cycle life (86% capacitance retention after 1000 bending tests). Such a flexible film is a promising electrode material for application in flexible supercapacitors.
Keywords: Nickel oxide; Graphene; Polyaniline; Supercapacitor; Flexible
1．Introduction
With the growth of energy consumption and the heavy demand for portable
electronic products, eco-friendly flexible energy storage devices have attracted widespread attention [1-3]. As a clean energy storage device, supercapacitor is currently a hot research topic due to its high power density, long cycle period, large charge quantity and high discharge rate [4-8]. Scientists are now committed to the research and development of nanostructured electrode materials that have good electrochemical properties and high specific capacitance [9-12]. However, for flexible supercapacitors, improving energy density and cycling stability while maintaining high electrode material capacitance remain a stern challenge.
Having good specific capacitance, conductive polymers are common flexible
electrode materials applied in supercapacitors; moreover, compared to metal oxides, conductive polymers possess higher power capability [13-14]. Among numerous conductive polymers, PANI is considered a promising one due to simple synthesis, low cost, environmental friendliness and high theoretical capacitance [15-19]. Nevertheless, because of the ion doping and dedoping effects, PANI shrinks and swells in volume during the charge-discharge process, which alters its skeleton and thus results in poor cycle life [20-22]. To overcome this shortcoming, scientists have studied the fabrication of PANI-metal oxide hybrid materials to improve the specific capacitance and cycling performance of PANI. Meanwhile, a strategy has been developed recently to coat PANI layer onto metal oxide/ carbon material binary hybrids, forming PANI/metal oxide/nanocarbon ternary hybrid with excellent capacitance and cycling stability. For example, Zha et al. [23] fabricated a ternary manganese ferrite/carbon black/polyaniline hybrid through a facile two-step approach. It was found that this ternary hybrid nanostructure can remarkably enhance the electrochemical performances, including the impressively high rate capability and excellent cycling stability (80% capacitance retention after 10000 cycles). Recently, Xiong et al. [24-25] had successfully designed and synthesized the ternary manganese ferrite/graphene/polyaniline hybrid through a facile two-step method. This nanostructure exhibits a high specific capacitance (454.8 F g-1 at 0.2 A g-1) and good
cycling stability (76.4 capacitance retention after 10000 cycles). It is of great interest to design complex metal oxide–based ternary hybrid system having high electrochemical performances. If that can be accomplished, then it should be possible to obtain much more effective supercapacitors. As a typical metal oxide electrode material, NiO possesses superior electrochemical properties, which is considered an ideal material for hybridization with PANI. Song et al. [26] fabricated PANI/NiO composites by self-assembly and found that the addition of NiO can improve the specific capacitance of PANI. Aleahmad [27] used different surfactants to prepare PANI/NiO nanocomposites, which have excellent electrochemical activities and thermal properties. To improve the conductivity of PANI/NiO composites, Huang [28] prepared PANI/NiO film using foamed nickel substrate and applied it in lithium batteries. Due to the improvement of conductivity, the film has good electrochemical properties. To further confirm that the NiO addition can improve the properties of PANI, Peng [29] theoretically studied the electrochemical properties of PANI/NiO composites, who believed that the structure and distribution pattern of NiO are critical for effectively improving the specific capacitance of PANI. Although the above studies have confirmed that PANI/NiO has good electrochemical properties, its fabrication as electrode materials with good cycling performance for flexible supercapacitor application has never been reported. To solve this problem, it is necessary to further control the sizes and morphologies of PANI and NiO by dispersing them on high surface area support.
In recent years, graphene has been considered one of the best materials for
preparing flexible electrodes because of its unique electrical and mechanical properties [30-32]. When used as a supercapacitor electrode material, graphene has low theoretical capacitance (about 100-200F g-1), but when incorporated into the conductive polymer, graphene can effectively increase the total capacitance while enhancing the material stability [33-36]. As graphene has large specific surface area (high radius-thickness ratio) and excellent mechanical properties, NiO coating onto its surface followed by composition with PANI is expected to optimize the ion diffusion channels and thereby improve the electrochemical and mechanical properties of
supercapacitors, which provides a new direction for the fabrication of next-generation flexible supercapacitor electrodes. Based on the above, it is of great interest to research the nano nickel oxide coated graphene/polyaniline composite film for flexible supercapacitors. To our knowledge, similar studies on preparation of flexible composite films are rare.
In this study, a novel nano nickel oxide coated graphene/polyaniline
nanostructure was designed as flexible supercapacitor electrode to overcome the limitations associated with individual components. As shown in Fig. 1, in the first step, a dense layer of nano NiO is formed on the GNS surface by hydrothermal method. Then, PANI is coated on the NiO-GNS surface by in-situ chemical oxidative polymerization methods. It is expected that the flexible NiO-GNS/PANI composite film can provide the improved performance of electrochemical capacitance and cycling stability.

sections.heading: 2.1 Preparation of NiO-GNS/PANI
sections.text:
The graphene oxide (GO) was prepared in accordance with existing literature
[37]. For a typical hydrothermal synthesis, 2 g of GO was dispersed in 50 ml of deionized water followed by addition of Ni(NO3)﹒6H2O (0.45g), C6H12N4 (0.5g) and C6H5Na3O7﹒2H2O (0.01g). The obtained solution was transferred into 100 ml Teflon lined autoclave tube and kept at 80℃ for 24 h. Once the reaction was over, the sample was allowed to cool to room temperature and the collected precipitate was washed and dried at 80℃ for 24 h. Finally under nitrogen protection, the product was sintered in a 400℃ muffle furnace to yield NiO-GNS. The NiO-GNS/PANI composite was prepared using in situ chemical oxidative polymerization method. Here, 0.1 g of NiO-GNS was dispersed in aniline (1ml) monomer and HCl (10 ml) mixture of 100 ml. The mixture was well stirred for 30 min. The 1.25 g of oxidant (NH4)2S2O8 (APS) was poured into the above mixture in an ice bath for 8 h. Then the solution was washed and dried at 80℃ overnight and the sample was named as NiO-GNS/PANI. Finally, NiO-GNS/PANI composite film was prepared by sol-gel spin coating
technique in accordance with previous report [38].

sections.heading: 2.2 Structure characterization
sections.text:
Microstructures of GNS, NiO-GNS and NiO-GNS/PANI were performed on a
JEOLJSM-6360LV scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and a JEM-2010 transmission electron microscope (TEM). X-ray diffraction patterns were recorded with the use of Cu-Kα radiation source (XRD; Ultima IV, Rigaku) at a scanning rate of 10°/min and a scanning range of 10-80°. The chemical structure analyses of samples were carried out on a WQF-31 Fourier transforms infrared spectra (FTIR) with the wavenumber between 4000 and 400 cm-1. Raman spectroscopy was performed on a Renishaw microRaman spectroscopy with wave between 0 and 2000 cm-1. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were conducted on a Scanning X-ray ESCALAB 250XI (Thermo Scientific) with C60 gun.

sections.heading: 2.3 Electrochemical measurement
sections.text:
Samples were measured by cyclic voltammetry and galvanostatic
charge/discharge in a three-electrode system using CHI660E electrochemical workstation (Shanghai CH Instruments Co., China). During the measurements, Pt served as counter electrode, while saturated calomel electrode was used as reference electrode. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was performed on CHI660E electrochemical workstation. EIS was recorded under the following conditions: the potential amplitude was 5 mV and frequency range was from 10 mHz to 100 kHz. The specific capacitance was calculated using the following equation [39].
mV
tI
mV
Q c

 
 
Where C was the capacitance, I was the charge-discharge current, t was the discharge time, V was the voltage difference between upper and lower parts, and m was the mass of active material.

sections.heading: 3.1 Characterization of the NiO-GNS/PANI composites
sections.text:
Fig. 2 shows the SEM images of GNS, NiO-GNS and NiO-GNS/PANI
composites. GNS was in a lamellar structure, which had a diameter of about 1-5 um and a thickness of about 10 nm (Fig. 2a). Large diameter and small thickness led GNS to have a large radius-thickness ratio (100-500), which had a large specific surface area. Fig. 2(b) presents the SEM image of NiO-coated GNS. As expected, the NiO-GNS is composed of many NiO particles decorated on the GNS surfaces. Further observations of the microstructure of NiO-GNS are shown in Fig. 2 (c, d), obviously, a great amount of NiO particles were coated on the surface of GNS, with a thickness of about 40-50 nm. Fig. 2 (e, f) shows the SEM images of NiO-GNS/PANI composites. It could be seen that PANI uniformly covered the surface of NiO-GNS, which exhibited a nanorod structure as well. This dense ternary nanocomposite with a large specific surface area could be an ideal electrode material for flexible supercapacitors. The morphologies of NiO-GNS and NiO-GNS/PANI were confirmed by TEM observations (Fig.3). As shown in Fig.3 (a, b), the particle size of NiO nanoparticles on the GNS was much smaller and more uniform, indicating that the GNS sheets could provide a good growth environment for NiO nanoparticles and confine the excess growth of nanoparticles. The composites of NiO-GNS/PANI is presented in Fig.3 (c, d). Notably, the PANI film combines with NiO nanoparticles perfectly. In contrast to Fig.3 (a, b), the NiO-GNS and PANI could be distinguished from the morphology of NiO-GNS/PANI, moreover, a thin PANI film covering on the surface of NiO-GNS was also recognized clearly, revealing the NiO-GNS/PANI composites were fabricated successfully.
FTIR spectrograms of NiO-GNS and NiO-GNS/PANI are shown in Fig. 4(a).
The characteristic absorption bands of NiO-GNS/PANI at 1552 cm-1 and 1453 cm-1 were attributed to the C=C stretching vibration of the benzenoid ring and quinonoid ring, respectively. Peaks at 1303 cm-1 and 1104cm-1 were ascribed to the C-N stretching of secondary aromatic amines and the N=C stretching vibration. Compared to FTIR spectrogram of NiO-GNS, the peak of NiO-GNS/PANI shifted from 547 cm-1
to higher wavenumbers of 630 cm-1, indicating that there was a strong interact between NiO-GNS and PANI, in accordance with the fact that C-H (in PANI) can preferentially interacted with NiO-GNS via its oxygen-containing functional groups such as hydroxyl. Furthermore, the red shift of all peaks of NiO-GNS/PANI also implies the strong π-π interaction between PANI and NiO-GNS as well as interaction between the nitrogen atoms of PANI (N-H) and the metallic ions of NiO.
The crystallinity phase purity of GNS, NiO-GNS and NiO-GNS/PANI were
identified using XRD analysis. Fig. 4(b) shows that the two diffraction peaks correspond to graphene’s (002) and (110) planes. Similar peaks were observed in NiO-GNS, it could be seen from the curve of NiO-GNS that the relative diffraction peaks at 37.4 (111), 43.6 (200), 63.6 (220) and 76.1 (311) were assigned to NiO (JCPDS 44-1159), confirming the NiO-GNS nanoparticles prepared. The XRD pattern of NiO-GNS/PANI presented a broad peak (10-30°), which were ascribed to the reflection of PANI. Besides, the diffraction peaks at 37.4° , 43.6° and 63.6° in NiO-GNS/PANI were much weaker than that those in NiO-GNS, implying that the crystal structure of NiO-GNS was well preserved during the polymerization.
Fig. 4(c) illustrates the Raman spectra of GNS, NiO-GNS and NiO-GNS/PANI,
respectively. Two characteristic modes of vibration of GNS such as D (1350 cm-1) and G (1600 cm-1) were observed. Herein, G band represents the sp2 carbon vibration, which corresponds to the first-order scattering of E2g mode, and D band represents the disorder degree of GNS layer, which corresponds to the carbon hybridization (from SP2 to SP3) [39]. Compared with the GNS, the NiO-GNS and NiO-GNS/PANI established the peak broadening and the observed D peak (1334 cm-1, 1340 cm-1) and G peak (1590 cm-1, 1602 cm-1), and the G peak and D peak were reduced significantly, indicating that PANI and NiO had already been coated onto GNS. The results above proved that the NiO-GNS/PANI composites was prepared successfully. Meanwhile, the characteristic absorption peaks appeared at frequencies of 1150 cm-1, 1340 cm-1, 1492 cm-1 and 1602 cm-1 are the C-H bending vibration of quinone ring, C-N stretching vibration, C-C stretching vibration of benzene ring and stretching vibration of C-C, respectively, and the absorption peaks at 390 cm-1, 528 cm-1 and 586 cm-1
correspond to the amine deformation and benzene ring deformation, respectively [41].
XPS was used to examine the chemical composition and structure of NiO-GNS
in Fig.5(a), the results further revealed the co-existence of Ni, C and O in the NiO-GNS. The Ni/O atomic ratio of 1/1.04 was close to the theoretical value for NiO. The C 1s spectra of GNS, NiO-GNS and NiO-GNS/PANI are shown in Fig. 5(b, c and d), respectively. The C 1s spectrum of the GNS could be deconvoluted into four peak components with binding energies at 284.8, 286.5，287.6 and 289.1 eV corresponding to the C=C, C-O, -C=O and -COO- species, respectively. Similar peaks can be fitted for NiO-GNS (Fig. 5(c)). Compared to GNS, oxygenated carbon peaks markedly decreased, which could be attributed to the hydrothermal reduction of GNS or NiO coating onto GNS surface. While in the decomposed C 1s spectrum of NiO-GNS/PANI (Fig. 5(d)), an additional peak at around 285 eV could be observed, which could be assigned to C-N, confirming the presence of PANI in the NiO-GNS/PANI nanocomposites.

sections.heading: 3.2 Electrochemical properties
sections.text:
To evaluate the electrochemical performance of the composites, cyclic
voltammetry (CV), galvanostatic charge/discharge and EIS measurements were carried out in 1.0 M KOH aqueous solution using a three-electrode system. Fig. 6(a) presents the CV curves of GNS, NiO-GNS and NiO-GNS/PANI at a scanning rate of 2 mV s-1. Usually, the shape of CV curves of GNS and NiO-GNS is related to inherent electroactivity, reactive electrolyte solution, scan rate and potential range. In a strict sense, the CV curve of GNS did not present the ideal rectangular shape due to its poor conductive property. Comparatively, the CV curve shape of NiO-GNS was improved. This was mainly due to the improvement of the conductive properties at high temperature sintering during preparation process. In addition, the integral areas of NiO-GNS/PANI in CV curve were obviously large than that those of GNS and NiO-GNS, respectively. This result indicated that NiO-GNS/PANI possessed better conductivity and higher specific capacitance. Comparatively, the curve indicated that the corresponding anodic peak at 0.4 V became very unobvious for NiO-GNS. Such a
difference was ascribed to the much higher conductivity of PANI. This relatively high anodic current response caused by NiO-GNS substrate could surpass the current response caused by PANI in the CV curve of NiO-GNS/PANI. Fig. 6(b) shows the galvanostatic charge-discharge curves of GNS, NiO-GNS and NiO-GNS/PANI at a current density of 1.0 mA cm-2. The shapes of the charge curves were almost linear and somewhat symmetrically mirrored their discharge counterparts, indicating the good electrochemical capacitance performance of these electrode materials. NiO-GNS/PANI obviously exhibited relatively higher capacitance than GNS and NiO-GNS. Through calculation, the specific capacitance of the three materials were 18, 402 and 594 mF cm-2, respectively. For NiO-GNS, a layer of PANI coating could improve its capacitive properties. Accordingly, it was reasonable to just regard the PANI as the predominant electroactive material and the NiO-GNS as the active substrates.
EIS measurements were carried out to evaluate the charge transfer resistance and
ion diffusion resistance of NiO-GNS and NiO-GNS/PANI. Fig. 6(c) shows the Nyquist plots and the equivalent circuit model used in the EIS experimental results, including the main elements of the resistors (R), the constant phase element (CPE) and Warburg element (W). The resistance values included the solution resistance (Rs) and the charge transfer resistance (Rct) within the electrode materials [45]. According to the previous reports, a larger semicircle means a higher charge-transfer resistance, and a steeper slope indicates a faster ion-diffusion rate [46]. It could be seen that the Nyquist plots exhibited a semicircle in the high frequency range and a near vertical line to the abscissa axis in the low frequency range. Comparatively, the NiO-GNS/PANI exhibited a smaller semicircle in high frequency and more vertical line in low frequency, which indicating lower electron transfer impedance and faster ion diffusion behavior than those of the NiO-GNS. Thus we could conclude that the NiO-GNS/PANI composites exhibited good supercapacitance performance.
More electrochemical tests were performed to evaluate capacitive performance
of NiO-GNS/PANI. Fig. 7(a) shows the CV curves of NiO-GNS/PANI at different scanning rates. At a low sweep rate of less than 2 mV s-1, the CV curve revealed the
sloping rectangle-like shape and current response was enhanced when increasing scan rate. In addition, at a higher sweep rate from 5 to 20 mV s-1, the CV curves obviously deviated from regular rectangle shape and the current response had an unobvious enhancement when increasing scan rate. This result indicated that the NiO-GNS/PANI had good electrochemical reversibility. Fig. 7(b) shows the galvanostatic charge/discharge corves of NiO-GNS/PANI at different current densities. All the curves were highly linear and symmetrical at various current densities, which implying that this composites had good electrochemical reversibility. Based on the aforementioned formula, the variations of specific capacitance at various current densities are plotted together in Fig. 7(c). It could be seen that specific capacitance of NiO-GNS/PANI shows the high specific capacitance of 1409 F g-1 at 1.0 A g-1, obviously better than that of NiO-GNS (796 F g-1). Encouragingly, with increase of the current density to 20 A g-1, the NiO-GNS/PANI still displayed a high capacitance value of 998 F g-1, which was distinctly superior to NiO-GNS (406 F g-1). It was worth noting that such a rate performance was also impressively higher than that of both NiO and PANI/NiO reported in the literature [8].
Cycling performance is an essential factor in supercapacitor electrode for
practical application. The cycling stability of NiO-GNS and NiO-GNS/PANI were investigated at a current density of 1.0 A g-1 for up to 2500 cycles (Fig. 7 (d)). It could be seen that NiO-GNS showed a remarkable drop in capacitance at the beginning and lost 32% after 1000 cycles during repeated charge/discharge. While for NiO-GNS/PANI, obvious capacitance decays occurred just before 1000 cycles, after that, the steady capacitance retention rates of about 92% was retained after 2500 cycles. This shows that the capacitance retention rate of NiO-GNS decayed rapidly because of the lack of PANI shield layers. Fig.7(e) shows the dependence of areal capacitance on current density calculated from the CV curves using Equation [47]: s (2 ) / ( )C i t S V    , where sC is the areal capacitance in F cm-2, i is the
discharge current in A, S is the surface area of the active materials in electrode in cm2, V is the scanned potential in V. At a low scan rate of 1 mV s-1, the areal capacitance
of the composite film is 176 mF cm-2. Evan at a fast scan rate of 20 mV s-1, the film could still deliver 68 mF cm-2. The capacitance decays with increasing the scan rate, which is caused by the relatively slow diffusion of the ions in the electrolyte at higher scan rates. Comparing with different flexible supercapacitor materials, the areal capacitance is much higher, as shown in Table.1 [48-52].
The enhanced electrochemical performance of this ternary composites is due to
the high surface area, low internal resistance, reduction of diffusion length and contact resistance between NiO-GNS/PANI/electrolyte, low diffusive resistance, large active sites and synergistic effect between individual constituents. (1) The enhanced electrochemical performance of NiO-GNS/PANI supercapacitor may be attributed to the well designed ternary nanostructure and combination of the superiority of each component. (2) The addition of GNS with highly conductivity can not only greatly improve the electrically conductive properties of the ternary nanocomposites, but also increase electrode/electrolyte area. (3) The presence of NiO nanoparticles on the surface of GNS may not only prevent the restacking of the GNS resulting in high surface areas upon cycling but also provide Faradic processes to increase the total capacitance. (4) The PANI layer can not only improve conductive pathways and restricts the dissolution of NiO but also be beneficial for enhancing the electrochemical performance by interaction with GNS.

sections.heading: 3.3 Electrochemical properties of bending film
sections.text:
To test the flexibility of NiO-GNS/PANI film and the influence of this flexibility
on electrochemical performance, the NiO-GNS/PANI film was assembled into a flexible supercapacitor using gold-coated polyimide film as current collector and encapsulation material, and cellulose membrane and 1.0 M KOH as separator and electrolyte, respectively [16]. The thickness of flexible supercapacitor was about 0.5 mm. The photo of the flexible supercapacitor and its schematics under different bent states are shown in Fig. 8(a). CV test was carried out at 2 mV s-1 when the flexible supercapacitor was bent from 00 to 900 (Fig. 8(b)). It could be seen that the supercapacitor showed perfect CV curves in the different bending angle (00, 300, 600
and 900), and no obvious changes in CV curves were observed. Moreover, Fig. 8(c) shows the changes in capacity retention after cyclic bending tests. It could be found that the capacity retention maintained at 86% after 1,000 cycles of bending tests. These inspiring performances of flexible supercapacitor could be attributed to the addition of graphene nanosheets, which may improve the electrical conductivity and mechanical properties.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
In summary, we have successfully designed and fabricated a novel
NiO-GNS/PANI nanocomposites film as electrode materials for flexible supercapacitor application via hydrothermal and in situ chemical oxidative polymerization methods. This nanostructure exhibits much higher specific capacitance (1409 F g-1 at 1.0 A g-1) and good cycling stability (92% capacity retention after 2500 cycles at 1.0 A g-1). The significant electrochemical performance can be contributed to: (1) The addition of GNS with high conductivity can not only greatly improve the electrically conductive properties of the ternary nanocomposites, but also increase electrode/electrolyte area. (2) The presence of NiO nanoparticles on the surface of GNS may not only prevent the restacking of the GNS resulting in high surface areas upon cycling but also provide Faradic processes to increase the total capacitance. (3) The PANI layer can not only improve conductive pathways and restricts the dissolution of NiO but also beneficial for enhancing the electrochemical performance by interaction with GNS. A flexible thin-film supercapacitor device based on NiO-GNS/PANI has been fabricated and tested. The device presents excellent electrochemical stability at different angles (0-900) and long cycle life (86% capacitance retention after 1000 bending tests). These inspiring performances would make this flexible film suitable for commercial supercapacitors.

sections.heading: Acknowledgment
sections.text: This work was financially supported by Principal Fund of Xi’an Technological University (XAGDXJJ1408), the Fund of Education Department of Shaanxi Provincial Education Department (15JK1362), and the National Nature Science Foundation of China (51303147).

metadata.abstractText: A nano nickel oxide coated graphene/polyaniline (NiO-GNS/PANI) nanostructure is designed and synthesized as electrode material for flexible supercapacitor application via hydrothermal and in situ chemical oxidative polymerization methods. It is found that this nanostructure exhibits outstanding electrochemical performances, such as high specific capacitance (1409 F g at 1.0 A g) and good cycling stability (92% capacity retention after 2500 cycles at 1.0 A g). The enhanced electrochemical performance of this ternary composite is due to high surface area, low internal resistance, reduction of diffusion length and synergistic effect between individual constituents. A flexible thin-film supercapacitor is fabricated using NiO-GNS/PANI, which presents excellent electrochemical stability at different angles (0-90) and long cycle life (86% capacitance retention after 1000 bending tests). Such a flexible film is a promising electrode material for application in flexible supercapacitors.
